text:
Chang-Yu Chang 張昌祐
Assistant Research Fellow
Email: changyuchang5@gmail.com
CV · GitHub · Google Scholar · BlueSky
Chang-Yu (he/him) began his fascination with biology as an undergraduate and later earned a master’s degree in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at National Taiwan University, where he studied beetle behavior. He then moved to the US for a PhD in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Yale University, where he investigated microbial community assembly and developed quantitative approaches to predict and engineer the emergent properties of microbial consortia. As a postdoctoral fellow in the Department of Biology at the University of Pennsylvania, he turned his focus to the evolution of host–symbiont systems. After several years on the East Coast, he returned to Taiwan in 2025 to join the Biodiversity Research Center at Academia Sinica as an Assistant Research Fellow.

title: Laboratory for Microbial Symbiosis, Ecology, and Evolution
text:
Community diversity is often greater than what pairwise interactions would predict. Our work has shown that multispecies communities can persist even when pairs of species fail to coexist, a phenomenon called emergent coexistence (Chang et al 2023 Science). Building on this principle, we aim to develop predictive frameworks for community assembly — asking when species combinations will converge on repeatable outcomes, and when history or chance dominates.








Microbial communities can be treated as evolving units, subject to artificial selection.
In experimental evolution systems, we found that community function can be improved by selection until heritable variation is exhausted (Chang et al 2020 Evolution). Our research identified strategies — stabilizing communities and perturbing ecological states — that extend this improvement (Chang et al 2021 Nat Ecol Evol). These insights point toward a design framework for microbiome engineering, where communities can be optimized for desired traits.








Facultative symbionts live dual lives: free-living and host-associated. Using population genomics and laboratory assays, we study how these multitudes of life stages shape the genetic diversity and divergence in microbial symbionts. Our work on host–symbiont systems explores how microbial symbionts adapt across hosts and environments (Chang et al 2025 bioRxiv).

title: Laboratory for Microbial Symbiosis, Ecology, and Evolution
text:
We are a new group at the Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan. The lab officially launches in November 2025, and we welcome applications at all levels. Join Us!
Our research sits at the interface of ecology, evolution, and systems biology. We study host-associated microbial communities— complex systems layered by hosts, symbionts, and mobile genes—with the goal of uncovering the simple rules that govern them. By integrating fieldwork, laboratory experiments, and theoretical models, we ask when and how diversity across multiple levels of organization emerges, persists, or collapses.
